data.text:
Even Old Bollywood was “Inspired” by Old Hollywood - Check Out 15 Songs We Must Thank The West For

During the mid-nineties everyone went mad at Anu Malik for getting too much “inspired” by Hollywood songs and remaking them in Bollywood. Our parents sing so high of the old golden days of Indian cinema with serene music that fell like honey drops to the ears. But did you know, Anu Malik was not the pioneer of getting “inspired” by western music? The tunes of far west have been layered with Hindi words since the very inception of Bollywood. But limited access to western songs in Indian households enabled this practice till recently. The revolution brought about by internet and presence of Youtube and zillions of other websites which has shrunk the whole world into a smart phone limits the music composer’s reaching for western “inspiration.” Let’s check out a few songs which you might have not known were an inspiration from the west.

Way back in 1954, Geeta Dutt lent her voice to the beautiful song “Babuji Dheere Chalna” for the movie Aar-Paar. Not sure if she knew that the song was a mere “inspiration” from the Spanish lyrics , Quizas, Quizas, Quizas, written by a songwriter Osvaldo Farrés that rose to popularity in 1947.

The 1955 movie, Munimji wasn’t free of Hollywood’s “inspiration” either. The hit song, “Jeevan Ke Safar Mein Rahi” was tuned on the notes of a Mexican hat dance. The only thing S.D burman did new was to lower down the tempo to match up the soft Hindi Lyrics.

I assume that most of our readers are millennials, so if you don’t know, ask your parents. They must have loved the song “Dil Tadap Tadap ke Keh Raha Hai” from Madhumati. Now when they tell you not to get inspired by the west, just tell them that their favorite song was a piece of “inspiration” from the Polish song Dzieweczka Do Gajeczka.

“Aaja Sanam Madhur Chandni Mein Hum” was sung by Lata Mangeshkar for the movie Chori Chori, released in 1956. The tune of the songs was though an “inspiration” from an Italian folk song “Tarantella Napoletana”

The famous ‘Mehbooba- Mehbooba’ song from the 70’s block buster Sholay was created when R. D Burman derived “Inspiration” from the song “Say You Love Me”. This original creation belonged to Demis Roussos’ 1974 music album, My Only Fascination.

Rishi Kapoor was unparalleled in dancing to the beats of “Om Shanti Om” on a revolving stage and gathering some massive fan following. But wonder if he was aware that this catchy number of Karz was nothing but an “inspiration” derived from Lord Shorty’s “Om Shanty Om”. Well, we did replace the ‘y’ by ‘I’. We hence claim the copyright for that ‘I’.

Apparently “Om ShantI Om” was not the only song of Karz which was inspired by the west. The next song of the movie, which turned out to be a cult in Indian cinema was “Ek Haseena Thi”. Music director duo, Lakshmikant Pyarelal were inspired by George Benson’s guitar chords for “We as Love”

When so many prodigious artists were “inspiring” Bollywood, how could the great Elvis Presely hold himself. So “The King of Rock and Roll” “inspired” music director Rahul Dev Burman through his piece “The Yellow Rose of Texas” and we had our very own “Tera Mujhse Hai Pehle ka Nata Koi” with a slower and soothing tempo. For this one, we still prefer the latter more.

Who can even forget the ravishing Zeenat Aman in “Laila Main Laila” from Qurbani. Well, from now on remember this song, not only for Zeenat Aman, but also as an “inspiration” from Black Bood’s song “Chicano.”

Amol Palekar and Tina Munim were adorable in “Baaton Baaton Mein” the choreography of “Na Bole Tum Na Maine Kuch Kaha” was super cute too. And cuter is the fact that this romantic song derived its “inspiration” from “When Johnny Comes Marching Home” which was apparently a Civil Wars Song. Now isn’t that funny!

“Koi Yahan Aha Nache Nache” from Disco Dance got fame to both Bappi Lahari and Mithun Chakravarti. And both of them owe their heartfelt gratitude to Trevor Horn and Geoff Downes who together formed The Buggles, and “inspired” Lahari with their number “Video Killed the Radio Star.”

This might not be a surprise. I think we all have growth up humming Peter, Paul and Marie’s “Five Hundred Miles”. And we all love its Indian “inspired” version “Jab Koi Baat Bigad Jaye” as much.

Hum Hai Rahi Pyar Ke ranks very high on the favorite movies’ list of any one born in the 80s, and no game of Antakshari was complete without “Yuhi Kat Jayega Safar Saath Chalne Se.” Here is the revelation, if you don’t know already, the song was “inspired” by the music of Demis Roussos’ “Lovely Lady of Arcadia”

While Anil Kapoor and Madhuri Dixit were expressing love to each other through the romantic words of “Tumse Milke” in “Parinda”, did they know that these words plainly sat on the tunes of Leo Sayer’s “When I Need you”?

And then we were all dancing our butts off to “Hare Khrisna Hare Ram” from “Bhool Bhulaiya”. I guess by then we all were smart enough to google out that the song was “inspired” by JTL’s “My Lecon”

Those accusing Anu Malik and Pritam for bringing plagiarism to Bollywood should rather realize, Old Bollywood, as it is, was never too far from Old Hollywood.
